Award.AwardTitle: NSWP: Photospheric Magnetic Evolution and Impulsive Solar Activity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigating team has recently used line-of-sight (LOS) solar magnetogram observations of a few dozen solar active regions (ARs) to develop a "proxy Poynting flux" parameter that they have demonstrated is statistically associated with flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs). In this project, the investigators will build upon and extend their previous work, in order to quantitatively characterize photospheric magnetic evolution and to statistically identify which measures of magnetic evolution are associated with solar flare activity. The quantitative study of AR magnetic evolution can constrain the physical processes leading to solar flares, which is a fundamental problem in solar physics.

This research team will analyze a large sample of ARs from the previous solar cycle, specifically using the full-disk, LOS magnetogram archives generated by spacecraft instruments, as well as a common magnetogram dataset that is part of a community Flare Forecast Workshop. In addition to their existing methods of quantifying magnetic evolution, the team will apply more innovative techniques in this project, including inductive flow estimation, autocorrelation, and evolution in magnetic multipole moments.

The proposing team will investigate associations between these new measures of magnetic evolution and flare activity, and analyze photospheric plasma flows in LOS and vector magnetogram sequences, as well as flows indicated by synthetic magnetograms developed from MHD simulations. This analysis will focus on the physical processes behind flare-associated measures of magnetic structure, such as strong-field polarity inversion lines, magnetic shear, and vertical electric currents.

The proposing team will partner with other researchers to coordinate ongoing community data analysis as part of the Flare Forecast Workshop. They also will assist researchers at the Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL) in implementing trial space weather forecasting techniques using the proxy Poynting flux parameter. Flow maps for the entire MDI archive and a database of parameters for a large sample of ARs will be produced and placed online, to allow wide use by other researchers. Undergraduate students will assist in analyzing data in this effort and will present their results at scientific meetings. This project will improve solar flare forecast accuracy, and thereby enhance operational space weather predictions and benefit wider society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs) can adversely affect many technologies used by our society, e.g., radio communications, satellites, and electrical distribution networks.  Although these phenomena are known to be driven by active region (AR) magnetic fields in the low corona, too little is known about the physical processes that produce these impulsive events to effectively predict their occurrence or strength.  Improvements in forecast capabilities would have clear broader impacts for our society.  Routine magnetic field measurements are only made at the photosphere (beneath the corona), but coupling between the photospheric and coronal magnetic fields --- evolution in the former induces changes in the latter --- means that studying time sequences of photospheric magnetograms (maps of the magnetic field there) can provide information about flare/ CME likelihood. In a pilot study of magnetic evolution in a few dozen ARs, the "proxy Poynting flux" (PPF) --- the product of the square of the estimated radial magnetic field with flow speeds estimated use structure tracking methods, integrated over each AR --- was identified as a significant predictor of flare activity.

 In this effort, we sought to characterize the predictive strength of the PPF in a much larger sample of ARs, relative to other predictors. (Previously reported parameters include: total unsigned magnetic flux in each AR, denoted TUSF; summed unsigned magnetic flux near polarity inversion lines of the radial magnetic field, denoted R; and prior flare activity.)  Its intellectual merit was to both verify previous results and determine the robustness of the PPF as a flare predictor. To do so, we first applied the FLCT tracking method to nearly all of the 96-minute cadence, full-disk magnetograms recorded by the Michelson-Doppler Imager during its approximately 15 years of observations.  The resulting collection of more than 72,000 flow maps, each in FITS format, is online to facilitate use by other researchers (a broader impact) at http://solarmuri.ssl.berkeley.edu/~welsch/public/data/FLCT_MDI_fulldisk/

We then used NOAA's daily Solar Region Summaries to identify the locations of all ARs at 00:30 UT each day, and computed summary magnetic and flow field properties within 10 heliocentric degrees of each region's NOAA location.  Next, we used NOAA's GOES flare catalog to correlated these magnetic and flow field properties with flare activity associated with each region.  Preliminary analysis indicates that the PPF is not a significantly better flare predictor than the TUSF and R parameters, which are both easier to compute. 

Beyond this main effort, we undertook additional, related studies.  We investigated the flare predictive power of PPF, TUSF, and R in a collaborative case study of three "Whole Heliosphere Interval" active regions, which produced modest flare and CME activity. We found that these quantities, while statistically associated with flares, cannot robustly predict activity levels in individual cases.  We investigated an innovative, fast method of characterizing AR electric fields (related to their flow fields in the ideal MHD approximation), but found its estimates to be noise-dominated.  We supervised three undergraduate research projects, which found: (i) CME occurrence is not associated with systematic decreases in model-derived, large-scale magnetic field strengths overlying their source regions; (ii) the emergence of new ARs is associated with enhanced flare productivity in pre-existing regions, but the effect is marginally statistically significant; (iii) CME velocities --- a strong predictor of their geoeffectiveness for Earth-directed events --- are jointly affected by (a) the amount of flux reconnected in associated flares and (b) the rate of decrease in model-derived overlying ...
